Refrigeration plays an important role at many of Exel, Inc.' distribution facilities across the country as it is necessary for safeguarding the products we handle.  Exel, Inc. Corporate Engineering Department, in conjunction with our design and build partners, has drawn on its experience with our other ammonia refrigeration facilities throughout the United States to develop a standardized design.  At minimum, this design meets and often exceeds all applicable federal, state, and local codes and standards.  At both the corporate and local levels, Exel, Inc. has taken significant steps to ensure safety both for its workers at the site and for the community at large.



It should be noted that the choice and introduction of ammonia as a refrigerant responds to current federal, state, and local regulations, as well as corporate commitments of  both Kraft Foods and Exel, Inc. to reduce the use of chloro-fluoro-carbon (CFC) and hydro-chloro-fluoro-carbon (HCFC) refrigerants that have been shown to cause ozone depletion and to have a higher global warming potential than ammonia. The City of Stockton restricts the use of CFCs, and the EPA has recently cited ammonia as a recommended refrigerant (EPA Short List of Alternative Refrigerants, EPA-430-F-93 004, February 1993). 



Construction of the addition to the ammonia refrigeration facility in Stockton is complete, with system operation that began in February, 1996.  Exel, Inc. has implemented strict standards in the development and design of the process and both the building itself and the addition, and has overlaid administrative controls for operating, testing, inspecting, and maintaining the facility.



DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY

The facility is located at 3735 Imperial Way, Stockton CA.  It is within the Arch Road Industrial Park, just Northeast of the intersection of Arch Road and California Highway 99.



The Arch Road Industrial Park contains many other facilities of equal and larger .



It is a modern, well-equippe

d, 160,000 square foot distribution center for the receipt, storage and shipping of Oscar Mayer and Kraft refrigerated products throughout northern California.



The overall facility site is an expanding industrial area, with no schools, hospitals or nursing homes within a one mile radius.  



Exel, Inc. refrigerated facility has been in operation since May of 1990. Since that time, the facility has not experienced an accident involving ammonia or any AHM outlined in the RMP. 



This facility has not had an accident involving AHM chemicals since we began operation in May 1990.  



Accident prevention is a high priority with Exel, Inc..  Exel, Inc. has corporate-wide goals, and procedures in place, to correct conditions that could lead to an accident.  The company takes numerous steps to prevent accidents and injuries, including the following: 



Develops programs to provide and maintain safe work environments



Provides employee training emphasizing safe work practices and potential on-the-job hazards



Performs periodic reviews of accident prevention programs and accident data to ensure that safe work practices are being followed



Provides incentive programs to promote safety awareness and interest among employees



All of these programs and provisions foster employee safety and awareness of potential hazards at each site.  Provisions are also in place for employees to report accidents or conditions that could lead to an accident. Any personnel injury accidents that do occur are reported in accordance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) requirements. 



The California Health and Safety Code requires that an RMP include a description of each "accident" involving the acutely hazardous material for which the RMP is being prepared that has occurred at the business or facility within the last three years of operation.  The description is to include identification of underlying causes of the accident and the measures taken, if any, to avo

id a recurrence of a similar accident. 



DEFINITIONS OF "ACCIDENT" AND FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 



The term "accident" (as it relates to an RMP) is defined in Section 25532 (b) of the California Health and Safety Code.  The Health and Safety Code uses the term "accident risk" to broaden the definition of accidents to include potential accidents or near misses.  The definition for accident is as follows: 



"... a potential for the release of an AHM into the environment which could produce a significant likelihood that persons exposed may suffer acute health effects resulting in significant injury or death."



Since the ammonia refrigeration facility at the Stockton site was constructed in 1990, there have been no accidents involving AHM.  As a corporation, Exel, Inc. owns and operates other ammonia refrigeration facilities.  Although not required by the RMP, accident data at these other facilities was reviewed.  This review determined that there were no ammonia-related accidents at any of Exel, Inc. currently owned or operated ammonia refrigeration facilities. 



Depending on the specific type of industry or process being evaluated, the definition of "accident" can vary significantly.  For instance, while the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) refers to "accidents" as incidents that involve worker injury, and does not specifically relate to release of hazardous material, Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA) Title lll defines specific federal reporting requirements for releases of hazardous material.  The SARA standards establish chemical-specific criteria for reporting releases based on the quantity of material released over a specified duration.  For example, any release of ammonia that exceeds 100 pounds in 24 hours must be reported under SARA Title lll requirements.  Unlike the OSHA standard, the SARA reporting requirements are independent of worker injury. 



There have been no such accidents at any of the Exel,

Inc. currently owned or operated ammonia refrigeration facilities.  In addition to not having any ammonia accidents as defined by the California Health and Safety Code, there were also no releases of ammonia in the past three years which exceeded the 100 pounds/24 hour release repeatability threshold required by federal reporting guidelines (SARA Title lll).



SYSTEM DESCRIPTION (Anhydrous Ammonia System)

Anhydrous Ammonia is the chemical used in the refrigeration system in this facility.  Refrigeration systems of this type are the most widely used in the world, primarily due to their reliability, safety and cost.  These systems are inherently safe and are designed and installed with automatic, computer-controlled monitoring systems to both indicate necessary maintenance procedures and sound the alarm in case of accident.  Ammonia is a lighter-than-air gas at atmospheric pressure and temperature and would rise quickly and disperse if released into the environment.  The primary hazard associated with ammonia is acute toxicity when inhaled or ingested. Ammonia also poses a hazard when coming into contact with the skin.



PRINCIPLES OF AMMONIA REFRIGERATION

"Refrigeration" is a general term used to describe the cooling of a space or substance to a temperature below the ambient temperature.  Mechanical refrigeration is an application of thermodynamics wherein a cooling medium, or "refrigerant," goes through a sequence of phase changes, the net effect of which is to absorb heat from one location and transfer it to another.  This process occurs in a closed cycle so that the refrigerant is recycled.  In the Exel, Inc. facility at the Stockton site, ammonia is the refrigerant.  In the ammonia refrigeration cycle, liquid ammonia expands, absorbs heat from the surroundings, ammonia vapor is compressed, condensed to a liquid, and then expanded.  As it expands, ammonia liquid changes back to vapor and absorbs heat from its surroundings, thereby providing refrigeration.  Aft

er absorbing heat, the vapor is compressed again, repeating the cycle. 



CHOICE OF REFRIGERANTS

Provides a comparison of some of the most commonly used refrigerants.  Until the early 1980s, CFCs and HCFCs were the most commonly used refrigerants.  These substances, however, have been demonstrated to have ozone-depleting properties and high global warming potential, thus posing a long-term danger to the environment and possible health risks.  Substances such as propane, butane, ethane, and ethylene can also be used as refrigerants, but when mixed with air, these substances are highly flammable and explosive. Therefore, they pose a significant risk to workers and the community. 



Ammonia is one of several available refrigerants not in either of these problematic groups, and has been used in refrigeration applications for more than 100 years. 



Most larger industrial systems rely on ammonia as a refrigerant.  Ammonia was chosen as the at the Exel, Inc. Stockton site for many of the same reasons it has been selected by other manufacturers:



     1. Ammonia is a highly efficient refrigerant.

     2. Ammonia does not have any ozone depletion potential.

     3. Ammonia does not have any global warming potential. 

     4. Although ammonia, like several other refrigerants, has toxic properties, it

          has many advantages over other refrigerants in terms of worker and 

          community safety:

 

Ammonia is easily detected by smell in concentrations well below levels that could be harmful. 

Ammonia gas is lighter than air and will rise and disperse into the atmosphere if released.  

Ammonia has a high affinity for absorption in water.  This increases the effectiveness of emergency response actions.



Exel, Inc. has extensive operating experience with ammonia and a proven safety record.  The company's standardized ammonia refrigeration design includes selected equipment for use in the system (inside the refrigeration building), which provides the pri

mary containment for the ammonia, including components such as rotary screw compressors utilizing thermosyphon oil cooling.



**Equipment and Operation

The ammonia refrigeration facility in Stockton is based on a standardized, risk-preventing design that is currently in operation at other Exel, Inc. facilities. 



The ammonia refrigeration facility at the Stockton site is new or recent construction, built to meet, and in many instances exceed, industry standards such as IIAR-2 and ASHRAE-15 (see Glossary), and other documents including the most recent Stockton Uniform Building Code (UBC), Uniform Fire Code (UFC) Article 63, and the Uniform Physical Code (UMC) Chapter 15.  The systems also meet the proposed revisions to the UMC and UFC.  These revisions to codes are supported by all the Northern and Southern Fire Prevention Officers (FPO) Code Committees of the California Fire Chiefs Association (CFCA).  All equipment, including piping, vessels, valves, instrumentation, and controls  are state-of the-art engineering design and construction.  The equipment is subject to inspections during construction and installation to ensure compliance with design and construction standards. 



 Wherever possible, ammonia piping connections are of welded construction. Welded construction provides the strongest, most leak-proof type of piping connection.  Flanged and possibly screwed connections are used for specialty equipment that cannot be welded, such as system relief valves.



The equipment for the refrigeration system is located in one of three areas; the Engine Room, the facility cool rooms and freezer room, or mounted on the building roof-top.



a)Screw Compressors

These transform cold, low pressure ammonia gas into hot, high pressure gas. This transformation is accomplished using single-stage screw compressors.



b)Condensers

These transform hot, high pressure ammonia gas into hot, high pressure liquid

. 

c) Expansion Valves

These allow liquid ammonia to expand

from high pressure to low pressure.  This causes the ammonia temperature to drop so that it can absorb heat.  The expansion valves also regulate refrigerant flow through the cycle.  Standard expansion valves act as the barrier between the high and low pressure parts of the refrigeration cycle. 



d) High Pressure Receivers

These receive and store ammonia in its liquid form.  These pressure rated vessels are designed, built, and inspected according to ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers) standards.  The receivers have the capacity to temporarily store a majority of the ammonia used in the system.  Periodically, the receivers are used to store ammonia to allow maintenance or inspection of other system components.  After passing through the ammonia receivers, ammonia liquid flows to the expansion control valves for each chiller.



E) Recirculators

These vessels, with ammonia pumps, supply liquid ammonia to the air handlers and receive the return suction for passage to the screw compressors.



F)Oil Pot Draining

Oil pots on the large recirculators are used to collect any oil accumulation.  This excess oil is drained as part of the routine periodic maintenance of the system.



G) Ammonia Charging

Ammonia is charged into the system through a charging valve located on the receiver vessel.



H) Air Handlers

These fan units operate in the cool rooms and freezer.  They are mounted near the ceiling and provide cooling by blowing air across cold, low pressure ammonia lines from the recirculators.



I) Auto-Purger

This device separates air and non-condensable gases from the ammonia, dilutes them with water, and disposes of them



2.  Detection, Monitoring, Automatic Control Systems, and Procedures

Administrative controls will be in place to ensure that actions resulting from audits are implemented in a timely manner.  The audit reports, as well as all RMP documentation, will be available for Administering Agency review. 



Exel, Inc. has assembled an RMP audit team under the lead of its Refrigeration Manager.  This team includes personnel from the operations, maintenance, and site safety departments.  As appropriate, Exel, Inc. uses corporate safety personnel, consultants, or individuals from other Exel, Inc. ammonia refrigeration facilities to participate in the audit and provide a level of independence to the reviews.  The team reports its findings to the Facility Manager, who reviews all findings and ensures that recommendations are implemented. 



It is the responsibility of the Facility Manager to ensure compliance with federal, state and local safety requirements and to ensure that any problems identified through internal audits are corrected within a reasonable time frame.  The various elements of the audit are outlined below. 



1.  Elements of the Audit



The RMP audit is carried out using a series of checklists developed by the audit team prior to the audit.  The following provides examples of the types of information that will be included in the audits.



Facility Inspection - Review of ammonia refrigeration facility layout to

ensure emergency access, proper component labeling, operation of

alarms, proper set points for automatic controls, availability of safety

equipment including fire extinguishers, SCBAs, etc.

This is accomplished through the use of design features that provide automatic system shutdown if critical parameters are beyond the normal operating conditions, local as well as remote monitoring of system operation, and numerous system controls and interlocks that alert the operator of any problems and enable the operator to shut the system down if necessary. 



For example, one unique accident prevention feature inherent in the Exel, Inc. ammonia refrigeration facility is that very little human interaction is required.  The refrigeration process involves recirculation of ammonia and, other than periodic system monitoring, there is virtually no need for operator involvement in the normal operation of the system, thus reducing potential risk of human error. 



In the unlikely event that a problem occurs that results in release of ammonia from the refrigeration system, a sophisticated ammonia detection system located throughout the ammonia refrigeration facility will sense the presence of ammonia, provide an audible alarm, and initiate safety systems and system shutdown if required.



AMMONIA LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM AND REFRIGERATION SYSTEM AUTOMATIC CONTROLS 



One of the single most important properties of ammonia from a safety perspective is its strong, pungent odor. Ammonia can be sensed by the human nose in concentrations as low 50 parts per million (ppm) in air. This odor threshold concentration of ammonia is well below the levels that pose a health hazard. Therefore, the odor of ammonia provides an early warning signal that allows people to evacuate contaminated areas and take protective actions long before significant hazards exist. 



Additionally, Exel, Inc.' ammonia refrigeration facility includes a sophisticated ammonia leak detection system that automatically initiates safety systems as well as local and site alarms.  The sensing system will be capable of detecting ammonia at concentrations as low as 250 parts per million.  It is important,

however, to assure that the alarms and the responses to them are commensurate with the severity of the problem.  For example, it would not be appropriate to evacuate the site for a small ammonia leak that would not be harmful.  Likewise, large leaks would require a greater level of response and initiation of precautionary actions.  For this reason, the ammonia detection system will have different responses for varying levels of detected ammonia concentration.  These responses will initiate a local alarm at 250 ppm.



In addition to the automatic controls associated with the ammonia leak sensing system, there will also be automatic controls associated with operation of the refrigeration compressors.  Each of the compressor units is controlled by a microprocessor.  Among its other functions, the microprocessor operates a series of interlocks which, in the event that pre-established critical parameters are exceeded, shut down the compressor.  As an additional safeguard, auxiliary system controls also exist to shut off the compressors if certain critical parameters for auxiliary equipment are exceeded.

As discussed previously, the ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop, recirculating process, with little or no need for operator involvement.  Under normal conditions, the operator's primary role is to monitor process instrumentation, providing information regarding process parameters such as pressure and temperature.  Under normal operating con

ditions, these process parameters do not vary to any significant degree.  Deviations from normal operation are therefore easily detected. 



The operator also conducts periodic inspections of the system to visually inspect primary system components, record critical process parameters, and note any abnormal conditions in the facility (leaks, excessive equipment vibration, etc.). These walkdowns are performed at least once every 24 hours.   



Because of the fully automatic nature of the system, the elaborate alarm system, and the limited need for operator involvement in the normal operation of an ammonia refrigeration system, there is no need for an operator to be present continuously in the ammonia refrigeration building.  For this reason, Exel, Inc.' standardized design for its ammonia refrigeration facilities includes a computer-based system that continuously monitors important system parameters and checks the status of the ammonia sensing system.  In the event that a critical process parameter deviates from normal range or a leak detector reaches an alarm setpoint, personnel at the remote monitoring location are alerted to take necessary corrective action.  The remote monitoring station for Stockton's refrigeration facility is installed in a central monitoring area in the Maintenance Department.  Security personnel can provide a secondary level of notification to contact appropriate Exel, Inc. individuals to respond to an incident.  

 



Exel, Inc. Preliminary Safety Review



Once the project scope has been defined, a Preliminary Safety Review is performed in order to obtain corporate approval.  The review may take several sessions.  The Preliminary Review examines the technical concept of the project, establishes the written process safety information that must be compiled, and assembles as much of this information as is available.  Information not available at the time of the Preliminary Review is identified and included as soon as it becomes available.  T

he results of the Preliminary Review address the following points: 



     1) Examination of the technical concept of the project:

          A? overall location and design of equipment and structures

          A? effects on infrastructure and utilities

          A? protective measures provided by process control systems

          A? potential process upsets and their consequences

          A? personnel exposure scenarios



     2) Compilation of process safety information pertaining to:

          A? the hazards of the process chemicals

          A? the process technology

          A? the process equipment

          A? overall hazards

          A? environmental impact





Exel, Inc. Process Hazards Analysis



During the Detailed Engineering Design Phase (development of specifications and system design), Exel, Inc. conducts a Process Hazards Analysis.  This analysis uses a systematic and comprehensive method to ensure that the finished design provides for safe and orderly construction, startup, operation, maintenance, and shutdown of the facility.  This review also includes a follow-up on the open issues identified in the Preliminary Safety Review.  The results of the Process Hazards Analysis address the following points:



     1) Analysis of Process Hazards:

          A? installation (facility)

          A? routine operation (process)

          A? non-routine operation (startup, shutdown, maintenance)

          A? emergency operation



     2) Follow-up on open issues from previous review(s)



A technique most often used for the Process Hazards Analysis is a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) Study.  The HAZOP study conducted for this facility is discussed in more detail in Section 5.



Exel, Inc. Layout Safety Review



The Layout Safety Review is also conducted during the Detailed Engineering Design Phase.  This review examines the overall layout of the facility, instrumentation, piping, valves, and equipment in regard to their impact on worker a

nd plant safety, fire protection, ventilation, safe operations, and maintenance.  A checklist is usually used for the Layout Safety Review.  This review also includes a follow-up on the Preliminary Safety Review and the Process Hazards Analysis to ensure that any safety issues identified have been resolved and any required changes have been incorporated into the design. 



Exel, Inc. Pre-Startup Review



Upon completion of construction, immediately prior to startup and before the introduction of chemicals or raw materials into the process, we conduct a Pre-Startup Review.  The purpose of this final review is to ensure that all safety items from previous reviews have in fact been incorporated into the actual construction, and that the process and facility can be safely started and operated.  This review also follows up on the results of the Preliminary Safety Review, the Process Hazards Analysis and the Layout Safety Review.  The Pre-startup Safety Review is usually done using a checklist. 



An actual walkthrough inspection of the process facility takes place after the team completes the checklist.  Any problems or exceptions are recorded and a judgment is made by the safety team as to whether a safe startup can take place.  Items identified as impacting a safe startup must be resolved before startup take place.  Startup cannot take place until the safety team concurs that a safe startup (and emergency shutdown, if necessary) can take place.  The project is not "closed" until all action items have been resolved.  The Pre-startup Safety Review addresses the following points: 



     1) Walkthrough inspection of facility

     2) Establishment of ability to safely start the process

     3) Establishment of ability to safely shut down the process

     4) Verification that the process and facility can be safely operated and

          occupied

     5) Verification of completeness of training

     6) Follow-up on open issues from previous reviews

     7) Review

of process safety information

C. Administrative Operating Control

Operation of the ammonia refrigeration facility is a straightforward process that requires very little operator interaction.  The system functions as a closed recirculating loop.  The operators perform system inspections, maintenance activities, and periodic testing of components.  The following controls have been incorporated into the standard operating procedures that apply to the Stockton site:



Operating procedures for the system are available in writing, in an easily followed format. 

The procedures include directions for system startup, shutdown, interruptions, and emergency situations.  There also is a written emergency evacuation procedure and equipment lockout/tagout procedure. 

Mechanisms are in place to ensure operating procedures, Piping and Instrumentation Drawings (P&IDs), and equipment, instrumentation and piping inspection lists are kept up to date. 

Operating personnel have trained in system startup, shut down, troubleshooting and emergencies. 

A control room walkdown has been performed to verify operating procedures are accessible to operators for reference. 

Provisions are in place to have supervisory personnel check on operators on a regular basis. 

Delivery of ammonia will be required to initially "charge" the addition to the refrigeration system.  Also, in the future, it will be necessary to recharge (replacing only a portion of the charge) the refrigeration system with ammonia, similar to the recharging of an automobile air conditioner.  It is estimated from past experience that the system may need to be done every 2-3 years. 

For the initial charge, or when a recharge is necessary, ammonia will be delivered to the facility by a certified vendor using a bulk storage tank truck.  These trucks are certified for safety by the Department of Transportation.  Some of their required key features include the following: 

Flexible charging line suitable for use with ammonia.

A series of valves on the unloading pipe of the tank that will facilitate a controlled flow of ammonia and provide safety features to minimize the chance of a spill and mitigate a spill if one does occur. 

Normal hand valve for controlling flow during charge 

Safety valve which can be closed from a remote location (approximately 15 feet away) 

Internal excess flow check valves, located on the inside of the tank, will work even if pipe valves break or get damaged.  This valve will shut off tank flow in the extremely rare occurrence of a pipe/hose breakage. 

Pressure relief valves are located at the top of the truck to relieve excess pressure.  These valves are of a "reseating" (resealing) type (spring-loaded to close when pressure is relieved), which minimizes any vapor escape.

Truck drivers are certified and trained in ammonia safety and use, and will be required to remain at the unloading station at all times while unloading takes place. 

At least two trained Exel, Inc. employees will be present at all times during the charge/recharge process.  Appropriate safety equipment and gear will be readily available and/or worn at all times during this process. The duties of the Exel, Inc. operators include: 



Close monitoring of all steps of the transfer process -- connections,pumping, disconnections.

Close monitoring of critical system parameters -- pressure, temperature, etc. -- during the transfer process.

Ensuring all procedures pertaining to the transfer process are followed.



E.  Administrative Maintenance Control

Exel, Inc. has developed a computerized Preventive Maintenance tracking system to monitor maintenance activities.  A computer program prompts maintenance personnel to perform Preventive Maintenance procedures as required by equipment manufacturers and Exel, Inc. policies.  Maintenance records indicate a component that requires maintenance and the type of activity required.  Completed tasks are entered into the computer. Preventive Maintenance

procedures are updated to reflect any changes required to improve maintenance activities or equipment changes. 



Maintenance personnel are trained through a combination of classroom lectures, vendor training, and on-the job training.  Outside contractors involved in maintenance activities on the refrigeration system are be trained in Exel, Inc. Safety Procedures. 



A key element to conducting maintenance activities in a safe manner is the Lockout/Tagout Program which controls potentially hazardous energy. "Potentially hazardous energy" is defined as any source of electrical, physical, hydraulic, pneumatic, chemical, thermal, or other energy that could cause injury or harm to an individual if unexpectedly released or not handled properly.  This program, originally established to prevent injuries to employees, created procedures to cover the servicing and maintenance of machines and equipment where the unexpected energization, or start-up of equipment, or the unexpected or sudden release of stored energy could cause injury to employees.  The program's objectives are: 



To provide safe working conditions for personnel who will be engaged in repairing, making changes, or performing maintenance on equipment which uses or produces hazardous energy sources. 

To assure a continued zero energy level during maintenance through the use of approved lockout and/or tagout devices and procedures. 

To provide for an orderly and effective energy isolation of equipment with minimal disruption to other processes. 

To ensure reliability and safety when returning equipment to operation. 

To lock out or tag a system to prevent re-energization until lock or tag is removed.



For the ammonia system, the program includes the use of a pump-out system in which ammonia is evacuated from sections of the system requiring servicing and pumped to the system receiver. 



Another key element to conducting maintenance activities in a safe manner is the Line Opening Procedure.  This proced

ure requires review and approvals prior to opening any line containing potentially hazardous materials.  This requirement applies to any part of a transfer system including not only piping but also such items as valves and connected devices.  This program was established to prevent injuries to employees and to prevent a release of hazardous chemicals to the environment.

 

G.  Inspection Procedures and Schedules



Exel, Inc. utilizes inspection procedures and schedules that have been developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration.   Representative copies of these are included in Table G - Other Technical Data.



H.  Maintenance Procedures and Schedules

During operation, inspections and monitoring of critical system parameters are performed routinely.  Preventive maintenance procedures are carried out by maintenance staff and supervisors on a regular schedule to ensure that all components are in their best possible condition.  Any deviations from normal operating parameters are observed and corrected. 



Exel, Inc.' maintenance programs for ammonia refrigeration facilities in use at its other sites have been adopted for the Stockton ammonia refrigeration.  These maintenance programs ensure that ammonia equipment is maintained in optimum working condition and that the facility is operated in a safe manner. Table 4-3 (pages 34-35) presents an outline of some of the maintenance and inspection programs for some typical ammonia refrigeration facility equipment used by Exel, Inc., and notes responsibilities for activities.



I.  Operational Inspections and Maintenance



Uninsulated Piping



Annually, all uninsulated piping and associated components such as flanges and supports should be inspected for any damage to or deterioration if the piping or its protective finish and remedial action taken where necessary.  Areas affected by slight corrosion should be cleaned off and appropriately treated before reinstating the protective finish.  Deeper pit

ting or loss of metal, where considered by subjective assessment to be greater than 10% of original wall thickness, should be checked accurately by using techniques such as ultrasonic measurements.  If such wall thinning is confirmed it is recommended that expert advice is sought, for example from an authorized inspection agency, to determine the need for and extent and timing of any replacements.



Insulated Piping



Any mechanical damage to insulation should be repaired immediately and the vapor seal reinstated to prevent access of water or water vapor which will lead to breakdown of insulation and corrosion of the pipework.



At least as part of the annual piping inspection, but preferably more frequently, the external condition of the insulation and supports should be inspected. 





5.  HAZARD AND OPERABILITY STUDY (HAZOP)

A Hazard and Operability Study was completed in conjunction with the preparation of the Process Safety Management Manual for this facility.

A.  Team

The study was performed by Kurt Liebendorfer and John Miller, consulting engineers from the Haskell Company, and Bob Chilcote, the Refrigeration Manager of this facility.

B.  Methodology

The HAZOP was completed as part of the development of the Process Safety Management Manual for this facility.  



As required by the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (29 CFR Part 1910, February 24, 1992), a process safety management program has been established at this location to properly identify, evaluate and prevent chemical releases that could occur as a result of failure in process, procedures, or equipment.



The program is designed to provide reasonable assurance that operation hazards are identified, that significant operational safety incidents are avoided, that operational safety requirements are considered in evaluating business decisions and that unacceptable risks to persons, property, products, and the environment are avoided.



The process includes all phases of pl

ant operations including conceptualization, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and decommissioning.



REQUIREMENTS:



Employee Participation - Develop written plan of action on employee participation; consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of process hazard analysis; and provide access to other information pertaining to process safety.



Training - Appropriate training in applicable tasks and procedures is provided to affected employees to enable them to perform their jobs safely and effectively under a variety of operating conditions.  For new employees, initial training includes verification that employees involved with a covered process have the required knowledge, skill, and abilities to safely perform their duties and responsibilities.  Written documentation of all training is maintained.



Incident Investigation - All process related incidents are reported in accordance with established policies governing actual or near-miss incidents.  The report is reviewed with all affected personnel including contract employees.



Hot Work Permit - A hot work and/or other applicable permits are issued for work performed on or near a process involving highly hazardous chemicals.  Documentation addresses fire prevention and that fire protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the work operations.  The documentation indicates date(s) and identification of the object to be worked on or near.



Emergency Planning and Response - An Emergency Response Team (ERT) has been selected and trained as part of the Plant Emergency Organization (PEO).  The ERT will respond to releases of hazardous chemicals including small planned releases.



Operating Procedures - Written operating procedures have been developed which provide clear instructions for operating the process safely and communicate to affected employees.  Procedures include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health conside

rations, and safety systems.  These procedures are readily accessible to employees and reviewed as often as necessary to assure they are current.



Mechanical Integrity - Testing and inspection procedures have been developed and implemented, which are consistent with applicable codes and good engineering practice, to provide reasonable assurance that the mechanical integrity of critical process equipment is maintained.  All equipment deficiencies are corrected before further use, or appropriate steps are taken in a timely manner to assure safe operation.



Contractors - Applies to contractors involved in maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  Consideration is given to a contractorA?s safety programs and performance prior to being awarded work on or near covered processes.  Contractors are informed of potential hazards, facility Plant Emergency Organization (PEO) plan, safe work practices in process areas, and their responsibility to maintain an injury/illness log.  Contractors are responsible for training their employees in safe work practices, documenting that training, and assuring that their employees know about potential process hazards (i.e. facility PEO and safety rules).  Contractors must also advise the site employer of hazards the contract work poses or hazards identified by contract employees.



Management of Change - A written procedure to manage changes to process chemicals, technology equipment, and procedures or changes to facilities that affect highly hazardous chemicals must be in place prior to implementation of the change, the impact of the change on safety and health, the modification to current operating procedures, time period for the change, and the authorization requirements for the change.  All the employees affected by the change are informed of and trained in the chance prior to start-up.



Pre-Start Up Safety Review - New facilities and modified sites of covered proc

ess perform a safety review prior to start up to insure that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications, all operating procedures are in place, and necessary employee training is complete.

L.  Training for RMP



1.  GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

Training of plant personnel is a key element in the overall safety of the facility because it ensures that personnel involved in system operation and maintenance are knowledgeable about job safety, hazardous material use, and necessary actions to take in the event of an accident or emergency.  Training programs focus on system operation, maintenance, and emergency response as they relate to material and worker safety.  Training programs ensure that workers are qualified to perform tas

ks responsibly, to diagnose routine and emergency situations, and to take necessary corrective actions including terminating or mitigating events to the extent possible.

 

2.  TRAINING PROGRAMS

All site employees receive basic instructions on the site general emergency response procedures.  This information outlines actions to take in the event of a site emergency, including notifying management or supervisory personnel of an emergency situation, actuating fire and other alarms, and taking protective actions such as evacuating affected buildings or responding to other evacuations. 



All employees who have the potential for exposure to hazardous materials in conjunction with their jobs receive additional training beyond the site General Response Procedure.  The level of additional training is dependent on the type of activities and responsibilities of the individual.  The following discussion outlines the various training programs for ammonia refrigeration facility operators, maintenance personnel, and emergency response team personnel.

 

a)  Ammonia Facility Operator Training

The Ammonia refrigeration facility Operator Training Program includes a comprehensive basic training module for new operators, refresher training for existing operators, and specific training programs for new systems and changes to existing systems.  Only persons experienced in refrigeration system operation are considered for open positions. 



New ammonia refrigeration facility operators are given formal training in the applicable portions of the OSHA general industry training requirements.  New operators receive instruction in the applicable Exel, Inc. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and emergency procedures.  Their progress is judged by experienced operators.  As part of on-the job training, new operators work with experienced operators on different shifts to learn, firsthand, system operating techniques. 



When a new system is introduced or an existing system is modified, t

he project engineer for the new or modified system is responsible for developing and modifying SOPs.  The new/revised procedures are developed with, and reviewed by, the operations, maintenance and safety departments.  The project engineer also is responsible for providing "hands on" system operator training for all new or revised systems. 



Operators are given refresher training on a variety of subjects including emergency response and plant safety.  In addition, they are encouraged to attend seminars and outside training sessions that can enhance their knowledge of system operations.



b)  Maintenance Personnel Training

Only trained refrigeration mechanics, electricians, instrument technicians, and other maintenance personnel are allowed to work on the ammonia refrigeration system.  Like operators, they are given formal training per the applicable sections of the OSHA general industry training requirements.  Maintenance personnel are trained in all of the procedures that are necessary to safely perform their work.  Operators and maintenance personnel receive training in Standard Operating Procedures, including procedures for Emergency Shutdown, Building Sump Monitoring/Pumpout, Equipment Maintenance Procedures, including procedures for Ammonia Charging, and Pumpout System Operation; and procedures for Emergency Response, Lockout/Tagout, Line Breaking/Draining, Water Treatment Control, and Ammonia Sensing Safety Equipment Checkout.

G.   Hazardous Materials Business Plan

Exel, Inc.A? Stockton Hazardous Materials Business Plan outlines the necessary actions to be taken in the event of an emergency.



The risks posed by the ammonia refrigeration facility are considered very low, since more than 90 percent of the ammonia in the refrigeration system has secondary containment in the building.  However, the use of any acutely hazardous material dictates a need and a responsibility to make both workers and the surrounding community aware of those risks, and to provide an understanding of the precautions that should be taken in the extremely unlikely situation the community were to be impacted. 



In the development of the revised Site Hazardous Materials Business Plan, Exel, Inc. will work with the County of San Joaquin and the City of Stockton to coordinate the various elements of emergency response and to define protocols for communication, organization, emergency response actions, and responsibilities.  In addition, Exel, Inc. is

developing a program for risk communication with members of the community in close proximity to the site. 



It should be noted that the evaluation of potential hazards that was conducted as part of the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and the Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) (see Sections 5 & 6), determined that a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system, should it occur, would have minimal offsite impacts.



In the unlikely event that an accident requires actions to mitigate or eliminate a release, a "refrigerant control box" located outside the facility will allow the fire department or emergency response personnel to relieve the pressure in each ammonia-containing vessel, mix the gaseous NH3 with water, and direct the mixture to the sanitary sewer;



Based on the safety features built into Exel, Inc.' ammonia refrigeration system (described above and throughout the RMP), it is considered highly unlikely that ammonia would be released from the refrigeration building.  In the unlikely event that a release does occur, automatic safety systems in combination with trained emergency response personnel will mitigate the event and protect workers, the community, and the environment.



Notwithstanding the low likelihood of such releases and the significant safety features that would mitigate an event that does occur, Exel, Inc. will take the necessary steps to ensure that all elements of emergency response are developed to address potential releases of ammonia.
